segments.text: Away we go.
This is Ron Shorn taping Tom Barnes at the University of California, Berkeley on June 8th, 1993.
Okay, let's try it.
For the record, Tom, what's your name?
Thomas Brady Barnes III.
And where and when were you born?
I was born in Columbus, Ohio on August 17th, 1944.
When did you first get interested in astronomy?
Really, during my freshman week when I was at the University of Rochester, I went there as a chemistry major and decided that I ought to be sure of that.
So I sat down with the catalog, read all the way through the catalog of majors and said, astrophysics sounds right.
I decided I had been more interested in astronomy through my growing up years than chemistry, so I switched majors.
When did you get your bachelor's degree?
1966 from Rochester.
And then where did you go to grad school?
University of Toronto.
Why?
I wanted to get, I wanted to do my work with, in Variable Stars and Don Ferney was, and still is, at the University of Toronto and he had done some really nice work on Cepheids, so I picked Toronto.
Okay, and when you got there, of course, you took classes and everything, but what did you do your thesis on and under who?
I did a master's thesis on secret galaxy variability with Don Ferny, and then I did my Ph.D. thesis also with Ferny on statistical parallaxes of MIRA variables to get the absolute magnitude.
Okay, then you get your Ph.D., and it's time to get a real job.
Where did you go?
I went to McDonald Observatory as a W.J.
McDonald Fellow in the fall of 1970.
How did that start?
Did you see a notice on the bulletin board or something like that?
In 1970, when I started making applications, the job market was really tight.
I mean, it got even tighter later, but it was pretty tight.
And so I applied for darn near everything I could find, and I honestly don't remember
where I saw the notice on it.
And I don't remember that I paid much attention to it as an application other than I sent it in, as I did a whole lot of other ones.
And then I got a call from Harlan Smith offering it to me in the spring of 70.
And I had a couple of other things pending at that time that hadn't been resolved.
One, for example, at the University of Western Ontario.
that after talking with various faculty members, I decided that I would drop out of the other ones and take the MacDonald Fellowship.
Okay, so your first contact with Harlan was over the telephone, but what was your first trip to Texas like?
Actually, I met Harlan before I went to Texas.
I met him at the IAU in Grenoble.

in uh in august september whenever it was in 1970 and uh i remember thinking when i met him that this is a character because every word he said about texas was it's the best in the world i remember distinctly him telling me about the accountant at texas keeping the books bill geist and how he was the best accountant in the world and i thought

This is really remarkable that everything there is the best in the world, because it wasn't quite the way I'd heard it from people before I went there, that there was some concern about, well, it was kind of a new department, a struggling department, but they had some big telescopes and a lot of access to those telescopes, which is why I went.
So I moved there in October 1970, and...
The department and the observatory were still housed in Painter Hall, the old physics building.
Right within close range of the Texas Tower.
That's right.
In fact, this was not long after the Texas Tower incident, and that actually didn't give me any pause.
I didn't consider that as a negative for going to Texas.
It was purely an astronomical decision.
When you got there, how...
Roughly, how big was the department?
I mean, how many staff and how many people at McDonald and the department?
I mean, it's hard for me to remember because it was almost 23 years ago.
But I suppose there were probably six or eight faculty, I guess, maybe ten.
I don't remember how many grad students there were.
The conditions in Pater were very crowded.
It was really, we were packed.

into that particular building the floors we occupied on that building right up into the attic so it was pretty crowded conditions but it didn't seem to bother people by and large in fact it was kind of nice in some ways because we interacted more strongly than when you're on three separate floors that's right um what did you do when you first went there uh well i went as a postdoc and so i got an office with uh with bill hubbard and uh and
Bruce, God, all of a sudden I can't remember his last name, Josephson Junction Fellow.
And I occupied the desk that Steve Little had before he left.
He was a previous postdoc.
So I started doing a program that I had planned to do, which was 4N hypersensitized plates of globular clusters to do VRI photometry of miras.
Okay, so you're using ammoniated foreign plates.
That didn't last very long because I discovered pretty quickly, even with the 82-inch telescope, that I wasn't going to be able to get what I wanted out of the plates.
And so I looked around for something else to do during the two postdoc years, and I discovered that David Lambert was working with Reinhardt Beer.
of Jet Propulsion Lab with a Fourier transform spectrometer on the 2.7 meter, which at that time was still third largest telescope in the world.
And this Fourier transform spectrometer was state of the art at that time.
It stayed that way for three or four years.
And it was fascinating.
It was highly mathematical.
They needed somebody with some observational experience involved.
And so I kind of fell in with that group.
began working FTS stuff for six or eight months and then David offered to move me on to one of these grants.
So I dropped off the fellowship and I stayed with Fourier Transformers for about six years.

One of the reasons I'm asking you is that you're at a place, and you're the assistant director now, I guess, at McDonald's, that is very heavily involved in planetary work, one of the few places it is.
But you're not really a planetary astronomer, so you've got a different point of view.
I mean, you're not going to lose your grant if you tell the truth, all right?
When you came to UT,
originally, what would you say was the status of planetary astronomy at that time?
Was it an integral part of the department, or was it a big deal, or did people just suffer it to be?
I think it was pretty clearly an integral part of the department from my perspective.
In fact, a lot of the time I spent observing with that FTS instrument was on planets, was on Jupiter, because that was what Reinhardt Beer was interested in doing.
We also did long period variables and some other things which were more of interest to me and to David Lambert.
But we got tremendously great amounts of observing time on a huge telescope, mostly because, I'm pretty sure, because of the planetary connection of that program.
In fact, I think my one planetary publication is I'm last author of about five or six on the first detection of deuterium off the Earth.
which was induterated methane in Jupiter from that instrument.
There was a lot of planetary astronomy going on on the 107-inch or 2.7-meter.
I mean, Ed Barker was there doing it.
There were a number of other people involved.
Bill Hubbard was there with planetary interiors work.
To me, it seemed like it was clearly an integral part of the program.
One thing that I think is a mistake in big and bright in the history of McDonald's is that no one who was not a faculty member at UT was ever mentioned.
So that leaves out Ice Spinrad, it leaves out Topia, and it leaves me.
And we all, between us, got a substantial amount of telescope time.
Was there ever any... And, of course, that was because NASA said, you know, you've got to use... We give you the money, you've got to do it.
Was there any...
jealousy, rage among UT faculty members about us outsiders using the telescope?
I don't remember any from then.
I remember a lot of that later.
But I don't remember any from then.
Now, that may be because I was so intent as a new postdoc in learning this system and getting established myself that I wasn't paying attention to it.
I also wasn't connected in to the faculty and those sorts of discussions to the extent that I am today.
So I may have just missed it.
But I don't recall there being any anti-solar system stuff at that time in the early 70s.
Was there, were planetary astronomers looked down on by real, quote, unquote, astronomers?
And this is like a Toronto and places like that that didn't have any planetary problems.
Were you aware of anything like that?
No, I wasn't.
I never got that sense at Toronto or at Rochester, although at neither place were there any planetary astronomers.
And so the topic most likely didn't come up very much.
Do you think planetary astronomy is real astronomy?
Sure.
Sure, I sure do.
I think it's exciting stuff.

Now, as I recall, NASA for many years had this block grant for planetary astronomy that they gave to McDonald, and then in, what, 88 or 87 or something, it was switched to individuals or something like that?
That's right.
I became aware of this later on when I got involved in administrative matters, but

NASA provided a facilities grant, or a block grant as it was called, to McDonald in exchange for access to the McDonald facilities, principally the 107-inch, by planetary astronomers throughout the U.S.
They had to compete for the telescope time, which in the early years meant that Harlan had to agree to give it to you.
Later, there got to be a pack and a real competition that was involved.
I was the last person in the world, and I guess because Harlan suggested I do it,
to write my letters asking for telescope time in pen and ink on paper.
He got a kick out of that.
But I mean, no kidding.
I would really write them on pen and ink in paper.
And I still got some Xerox copies of that stuff.
And I guess he was the last observatory.
I mean, he was the last old-time observatory director that made the decisions without a...
observing committee or anything like that.
Is that true?
That's right.
During most of the 70s, now I'm not sure what year it changed, but it was right around 1978.
It may have been a year or two earlier or a year or two, certainly not more than a year or so later, that prior to that time, Harlan kept a huge poster board of graph paper, basically, on

in his office and he had each telescope and he had the calendar on the x-axis and each telescope was listed on the y-axis and he would write in and pencil the observing programs and since and he wrote him in on pencil because he would change them right up to the day of the run there were times when when my observing runs were were changed at the last minute for a variety of reasons none of which seemed to me good at the time but i'm sure they were good in his eyes

uh and that went on until um uh as i say the late 70s when the scheduling was turned over to david evans and then maybe pretty quickly rob robinson uh began helping him with it and they did it in a similar way in the sense that they had golf tees and pegboard and they they reproduced harlan's uh
graph paper system and a different mechanism, but it was still the same thing.
You submitted your proposals.
They sort of read them and decided who got telescope time and put the pegboard up accordingly.

And then it was in the early to mid-'80s, we went over to an actual TAC, the Telescope Allocation Committee, which reviewed the proposals, made decisions, and those decisions were honored by Harlan and now by the current director, Frank Batch.
Honest Engine Scout Center is committee allocation of telescope time better than beneficent despot.
I've thought a lot about that because I've seen both of them at Texas, and my conclusion is that from the point of view of the science that gets done, I don't think it makes a worth of difference.
From the point of view of the feelings of the people getting

Proposing for time and getting the time it makes a tremendous difference because When there's a group of colleagues who evaluate one's proposal come to their best decision and then render that judgment
there is more acceptance than when a single individual says, I've made the decision based on my best reading of the circumstances.
So I don't think it makes any difference in the science that gets done.
I don't think it made any difference when it went from Harlan to David Evans to the TAC in who got telescope time.
I haven't done the statistics to prove it, but I don't believe there was any difference.
But there was a tremendous improvement in the acceptance of the telescope schedule by the people listed on it.
Now, currently, you're the assistant director at McDonald's, and Frank is on vacation.
So I'll hit you, because usually it's like the co-pilot always lands the plane.
The assistant director does all the work.
What's the status of planetary astronomy at UT and Texas today?
I think it's as healthy as it was at any time in the history of Texas.
There's obviously the difference that there is not someone with an intense interest in planetary astronomy in the directorship position.
That changed when Harlan retired as director and Frank came in.
Frank's a radio astronomer interested in galaxies, in galactic structure.
And he's not hostile to planetary astronomy, but it's not of intense interest to him such as it was for Harlan.
So that changed.
The quality of the research hasn't changed at all.
We've got both the Cochrans are still there.
Larry Trafton's there.
Ed Barker's there.
There are a couple of postdocs that have come and gone working in that area.
Artie Hotzis is there now working with Bill Cochran.
The emphasis of the program has changed somewhat as the years go by, but that's normal in any research program.
I think the quality of the program now is as good as it's ever been.
The amount of telescope time granted to planetary astronomy in this competitive attack environment has stayed high.
It consistently exceeds the amount of time that's been funded by NASA.
We still get quite a few outside observers coming in.
There's Drew Potter from JSC.
There's Alan Stern from Southwest Research.
Institute and others who come in to make use of the McDonald facilities.
So I think it's as healthy as it's ever been.
Here's something that goes for astronomy in general as well as planetary astronomy.
Times are getting tough, folks.
What do you see in the future?
And I think planetary astronomy will just, because we both agree it's part of astronomy, so it's going to rise and fall with the tide.

What do you think's in the future for the next couple of years in a couple of decades With respect to planetary astronomy I Think for McDonald things are really looking up McDonald overall fields because on April 1st the Regents approved the spectroscopic survey telescope which is
The primary will have a hexagonal shape, 91 hexagonal segments put together to make a hex primary, which will be 10 meters by 11 meters.
So it'll be a huge telescope to go at McDonald, assuming that we can get all our partners to sign the legal agreements and that the bids for construction come back within budget.
We will have that in full operation by sometime in 1997.
And you're going to put it on flat top?
It'll be on flat top.
Which is now called Mount?
Mount Fulks.
Right.
But it's flat top to us all the time, right?
Right.
So I see the prospects from McDonald being outstanding.
And the spectroscopic survey tells us, though, that we dedicated the spectroscopy in a four-minute field of view, so it's not appropriate for large-scale imaging, small imaging, okay.
I see planetary astronomy having a very, very big role to play in that.
One question that I have on my list here is how well do you think astronomers in general and planetary astronomers in particular have sold their field?

And it's particularly appropriate to ask you because I think McDonald has done a tremendous job compared to, say, Mount Wilson and Palomar, who generally have a the public be damned attitude, I think it's fair to say.
What do you, I mean, you're obviously doing a lot with the general public, and as you know, Susan Shorn is the assistant editor for Star Date.
That was Harlan's idea to do it, and do you think that has worked out well to really get the public involved?
Oh, yeah.
It makes a tremendous difference in how we are treated within the state of Texas by the legislature and the university.

Frank has said to me that he has sat in meetings with prominent members of the legislature, or lunches with prominent members of the legislature, and friends of the observatory who are discussing the role of McDonald with these people, who have said,

that their connection to McDonald is through Stardate, through the magazine, through the radio program, that they take great pride in driving through Washington, D.C., and hearing on the radio Stardate come on in reference to the University of Texas at Austin.
So our public outreach program is very effective for us in maintaining a presence with the political structure in the state of Texas.
But that's, I mean, that is a reason for doing it.
It's not the primary reason for doing it, in my mind, nor was it in Harlan's, nor is it in Frank's.
That's a spinoff from, you do it because the people who have paid the bill for all of our research have a right to hear the results from that research in a way they can understand.
You have a
Huge number of other things going on with the public, you know, little observing sessions down at the visitor center and the visitor center.
Have you ever thought about painting the shutters yellow and putting up a McDonald's on the mountain?
Because everyone always expects...
McDonald's Golden Arches.
I know the public oftentimes get confused between McDonald's, the restaurant chain, and McDonald's Observatory, but no, we haven't actually thought about putting Yellow Arches out there.
Maybe if the funding situation gets better.
Have you ever approached McDonald's?
No, not that I know of.
Because, I mean, I don't know how many times I've been on the mountain, people say, you know, where do we get the hamburgers?
And the second question is, where's the gasoline station?
Right.
And where's the restroom?

But that is in marked contrast to a number of other observatories that we could name, that probably because they had private funding sources, and I'm talking about Molson and Bellarmine, had only discussed for the general public.
There's two things that underlie that, I think.

one of them is that in the will from w.j mcdonald in which he gave the bequest to the university to uh like to erect and equip i can remember the quote it's something like to erect and equip an astronomical an observatory for the study and the promotion of the study of the science of astronomy and that promotion of the study of the science of astronomy in his will
has been used as the justification for a strong public outreach program.
But I think that reason is more of a post-hope justification rather than something that started it.
It really started and was maintained and grew because Harlow Smith believed in it.
He was absolutely dedicated to a strong public outreach program.
It was one of the key things he wanted to accomplish, and he did accomplish it.
personal opinion, why do you think that kind of attitude is so rare among astronomers?
Especially since now, basically, we're all supported by public opinion one way or another.
You know, I think the root reason for it, in my mind, is that most researchers are not very facile in dealing with other people.

They're outstanding in dealing with the technicalities of the science, in dealing with the mathematics, with the instrumentation, with the observing programs, with the observing plans, with the getting of the money, the writing of the grants, the writing of the papers.
But in everyday normal social environments, I think an awful lot of high-tech researchers, like astronomers, are not very facile.
and that they're uncomfortable with it.

So there's a tendency to focus in on the nitty-gritty of the research and stay away from, and therefore later to put down, the part of research where it's communicating at a very elementary level the fundamentals of what we've discovered.
And unless you're really good at communicating with the public, such as Harlan was, or to use the current example, Carl Sagan, unless you're really good at that,

it's hard to do and if it's hard to do people tend to stay away from it if they stay away from it then they tend to think well that's not very important because i'm not in it it's not very important it tends to be downrated all right now now it's time for funny stories um all right you got any funny harland smith stories
I mean, for example, in Big and Bright, they never mentioned the spectrum of the Swiss Army knife, which is probably before your time.
That was before my time.
I've heard that many times, never directly from Harlan, so I can neither confirm nor deny it.
What was the story?
Well, the story was that, in fact, I did hear that from Harlan one time.
I did hear that from him one time.
He mentioned it to me once with respect to

i can't remember what to respect but in any event the story was that he was observing on the 82 inch telescope at coup day and that um the iron arc spectrum which was produced by two electrodes uh close to each other and a high uh electrical current flowing between the citizen arrangement right so it just gave you a big bright arc um that the arc was weak and that
Harlan said, well, we need to adjust the arc to make it brighter on the plates.
And so he pulled out his handy Swiss Army knife and inserted it between the electrodes to make the adjustment with the power on.
And it is said that, in this story, I don't know if it's true or not, that it vaporized the blade of the knife, which is...
And you can also see molecular bands from the handle of the Swiss Army knife.
Because the shutter was open, wasn't it?
I don't know that.
Supposedly there is a spectrum that exists.
Well, I've heard that.
I don't know whether that's true.
It's also told that Harlan went out and threw the knife down the mountainside.
Now, that does not sound like Harlan.
I don't believe that happened.
It doesn't sound like Harlan.
I don't think he would do that.
But whether there's a plate that shows these, I don't know.
Any other stories?
Well, Harlan, he had a tendency to focus in his mind on what he was doing to the exclusion of other things going on around him.
And we spent quite a few nights observing on a project to attempt to measure whether or not there was a time limit
cosmologically time variability in Planck's constant.
This was in the early 70s.
And we did a lot of cast grain observing on the 107 at that time together.
There were several nights when we would have the platform up off the floor, raised up to get access to the cast instrument, and Harlan would say,
I'm going to check the weather, which meant going outside on the catwalk and walking around the dome.
And he would just charge for the door and walk right off the platform.
Now, at no time was the platform more than maybe two feet off the floor on any of these occasions, but it would happen night after night.
He would be so focused on what he was doing that he wouldn't pay any attention to his surroundings.
And he would fall off and skid along on the floor and look back and say, I must remember not to do that.
And then he'd do it again.
Do you think Harlan could have done even more had he done a little less?
I think that's a very good question.
It goes to the heart of what Harlan was like in his research and his directing, which is that
He attempted to move on all possible fronts simultaneously.
And it worked like a champ when there was lots of money.
Because he would fund nearly everything.
He never met an idea he didn't like.
And that meant we had an incredible number of things going on simultaneously.
And that was great when there was money to support them.
Because some would plan to pan out, some would not.
And if they didn't pan out, he'd let them go, with some exceptions.
But when the mid-80s hit, and suddenly money began to get tight when the second oil crunch hit, and literally the depression hit in Texas.
And the 300-inch telescope got eliminated.
We entered an environment in which money was ever tighter.
And that mode of operation of expanding on all fronts, funding everything possible,
was simply incompatible with the fiscal situation.
And it got more and more frustrating for Harlan as he attempted to do this and could not.
And I think that was one of the key reasons why he chose to retire from the directorship in 1989.
That he had, McDonald Observatory had entered an era in which it wasn't fun for him to be director anymore.

When we had lots of money, I think if he had focused it on fewer efforts, we would have made a lot more progress in those efforts, but there may have been some other things that we accomplished that never would have got started.
It's a different style, the two different styles.
It wouldn't be Harlan if he was different.
It wouldn't have been Harlan.
He was not focused like that on specific research areas.
a tremendously broad interest.
I got a lot of comments the other week at Austin about the fact that Harlan was loyal and maybe sometimes too loyal, and we're talking here like image tube and everything like that.
Yes.
Which I guess is the greatest fiasco of his reign.
Yes.
Did they ever get anything out of that?
They brought the , the electronographic image tube was brought to the point where it actually obtained astronomical data that were never used.
to the best of my knowledge, they were never used because there were no astronomers tied into the particular program.
That is that that development was funded by Harlan and conducted by Paul Gribbavel with almost no astronomical expertise attached to it.
There were no astronomers demanding that this get operational so I can use it for my research.
There weren't any.
And so when it became operational, there weren't any to use it.
And it became operational almost at the same time that CCDs came in.
There was a period of a few years where the river ball camera could have been used for astronomical uses, but it was too late.
There were no astronomers involved.
By the time any astronomers could have got involved, CCDs had beat it.
Do you think you, and I talked to Greg Shields, and I'll let you know, maybe I did tell you the other night,

But we were talking in the library last week, and we both felt that actually in both of us, there was only one time in the 30-some years that I've known Harlan almost as long as Greg that we ever got to know the real Harlan.
When you met him, he was open and all that, but do you think there was still a little curtain or something like that?
Oh, yeah.
I worked really closely with Harlan for 11 years.
I had the shared secretary in the office between us, and I saw him every day.

I felt that there was always a distance between us almost always now there were times when that would break down and that's not to say it's not because he was a formal guy it's just as you say there was this veil this curtain that the inner workings of harlow smith were not always visible that it was very hard to know him as just another human being uh he was uh

very closed in that respect he was he was intensely loyal as you say he was he was generous but i never really felt that i knew the real harlan except occasionally i would see it and one time i mentioned to you the other night that what was very obvious i was seeing the real harlan was when he called frank bash and me into his office or into frank's office
this was after Harlan had quit as director, and told the two of us that he had been diagnosed with cancer, that it was going to be really touch and go as to whether he could be cured from this.

uh and he was clearly very emotional about it and frank asked him a question that had to do with well to concentrate on winning this battle are you you told chairman are you planning to lead the faculty and not teach in the fall because he was scheduled to teach and harlan said uh he said no that he was he was going to tell the chairman but he was going to teach in the fall he was going to stay on the faculty he was going to continue his appointment not take retirement because
The only security Joan had was his pension.
And as he said that, he literally teared up.
And I have never seen Harlan do that.
I've never seen him do that before.
And this was a real person coming through, that he cared deeply that Joan have whatever security he could leave her if he didn't make it through this illness.
There were other times when he
He was generous and I could see a real human being there.
I had a bruising battle with David Evans one time over the telescope schedule in which I overstepped my bounds somewhat in a way that was inappropriate and irritated David.
David was right.
He had a very strong right to be irritated with me.
And so we ended up having a public meeting in which we

disagreed strongly with each other and at the conclusion in which a decision needed to be taken as to which of us was going to win and i was already harlan's at that time i was assistant director and at the end of the meeting harlan chose david's position and uh and when i got back to my office after that i had a small scrap of paper which had obviously just been torn off of some other larger piece of paper
onto which was affixed a band-aid.
And next to the band-aid, Harlan had written, one band-aid for one bruised ego, H. It was a nice touch.
It took an awful lot of the sting out of him siding with David.
He was right to do so, but it was a nice touch.
It was the kind of thing that Harlan would do most unexpectedly.
Do you think that Harlan's gung-ho, let's go get him attitude started to fall on the authorities in the last few years, the authorities at the University of Texas?
I've heard that.
Yeah, I think it did.
I don't think they were, I think they respected Harlan's power, but I don't think they really liked him.
I give you an example.
When we were working to get the 300-inch telescope project approved, no, I'm sorry, let me back up.
Let me give you a different example.
When we were, at one time, the Space Telescope Science Institute was up for grabs.
Where was it going to go?
And Harlan wanted it to go in Austin.
And so we were trying hard to get it.
And he was
At that moment, we were changing presidents at UT Austin.
From who to who?
We were going from Maureen Rogers to Peter Flong.
And Jerry Falcon, who's now the provost and executive vice president of the university, and has been for many years,
He was executive assistant to Lorraine Rogers.
I don't know his exact title, but he was her right-hand man in her office.
He wasn't vice president of something or other.
So we were working through him, and we were trying hard to get the university to put in a proposal for SDSCI.
And we went to Jerry and said, can we do this?
And Jerry said, he said, Harlan,
He said, I can't get this done.
He said, I'm between two presidents here who can't deal with this.
OK, well, after the presidency changed, we went to Peter Flon.

uh we met him in the basement office of the geology building i believe and he was in this little bitty cubicle but he hadn't quite become president yet and we harlan and i went to him and spoke to him about this project and peter flawn had been at ut austin when harlem was building the 107-inch and he knew harlem and he'd been president after that he'd been president ut san antonio
So I looked him in the eyes and said, I know the way you operate.
I know the way you work.
And I need you to tell me the truth on this.
Have you already gone around me to the UT system on this project?
And Harlan said, absolutely not.
I would not do that.
I've got to work with you through channels.

And I sat there dumbfounded because I had personally delivered the materials to Executive Vice Chancellor Jim Duncan on this matter down at UT System and had Duncan look me in the eye and said, you realize this is out of channels?
And I said, yes, sir, I know that.
My instructions are to give you this stuff.
The UT administration knew how he worked.
They respected his power, but I don't think they liked him.
And so Harlan really had a vicious streak.
He could double deal when it was necessary.
That's right.
Not vicious, I mean.
Vicious is not right.
It's more that he had a very strong belief in his rightness.
in that he was right, and that to some extent, he'd never have said it this way, but to some extent, the ends justified the means.
It was classic in faculty meetings when I was on the faculty.
It was absolutely classic the way he would handle the faculty, in that he had a proposal.
He would bring it to the faculty to discuss as was right and proper.
There would be a majority opposed to him, and so he would say, it's clear we have not reached consensus on this yet, so let's continue the discussion later.
And he would literally continue the discussion until he had a majority.
He would never let it not happen.
He knew he was right.
I mean, he had no question but that he was right.
And I'm going to change the subject.

One of the things I put in this proposal that NASA bought was that any good observatory, if they're lucky, has somebody, and in the case of McDonald's, it's Bob Tull, whose equipment we have all used.
And yet, those kind of guys don't get to write scientific papers, and there's a guy, John Geary, for example, at the Center for Astrophysics, who's the Bob Tull of the Center for Astrophysics.
Without them, we'd all be dead meat.
Right.
Right.
Bob Tall is still alive and well and kicking, but how do you handle those people?
How do you keep them on the payroll?
I mean, they're necessary, but they don't meet, I mean, they're absolutely vital, but they don't meet the qualifications of the philosophy department or the English department or whatever.
The way Harlan did it with Bob Tall was that

Just before I got to Texas, I don't know how much before, maybe the same year I got there, Bob was denied tenure, a promotion from assistant professor to associate professor by the faculty, I assume based on publication criteria.
Weight of paper.
Weight of paper and number of publications and science done.
Whereas he was clearly an unbelievable talent, a world-class talent in instrumentation.
So Harlan told me later,
And he said this a number of different times in all the time I knew him.
So it's something that I know happened, although I wasn't there to witness it.
And he said that after that decision was taken, he told Bob Tull that as far as he and Harlan Smith was concerned, Bob Tull had tenure.
And that Bob Tull had a job at McDonald's as long as Harlan Smith had a job at McDonald's.
And indeed, he would let himself go before he would let Bob Tull go.
And that's the way it happened.
How important has Bob been to astronomy at UT?
Crucial.
Absolutely crucial.
Because our history through the 70s and 80s was based on our excellence in coup de spectroscopy.
And that excellence was built by a number of different people.
For example, David Lambert, who was clearly
one of the finest observational astronomers in the world, doing two-day spectroscopy.
But his success was built on the foundation that Bob Tall built.
And if Bob Tall had not been there, MacDonald wouldn't be one-half, one-third what it is today in terms of recognition throughout the astronomical community.
He was absolutely crucial.
Do you think that the...

the last minute uh decision to you know strike out the 300 inch you know the last hour of the legislation you think that took a lot of steam out of harlem yeah it did um during that period of time that's all harlem did was uh was the 300-inch telescope and

uh when when it was lying the primary mirror money was lined out of the state budget because of the oil crisis it set us back from a project that was on its way to probable success i won't say certainty probable success to a project that was most likely not going to happen and harlan didn't really recognize that for a little while he kept pushing it really hard
And as late as the year when Bill Cunningham became president, changing over from Pete Flong, I forget what year that was.
It was probably 86 or 87.
We had a breakfast meeting, Harlan and I and key members of the Board of Visitors, with Bill Cunningham right early on in his tenure as president.
brought up the 300 inch telescope and Bill looked him straight in the eye and said quite loudly to the whole table, he said, Harlan, the 300 inch telescope is dead.
Forget it.
And I think that was when it really became clear to Harlan that it was over with.
Did the torpedoing of the 300 inch have any effect on the general faculty and staff at McDonald's?
I mean, were you guys in a dump, sir?
Yeah, I think there were several years where
We were kind of at a loss because it was obvious that we needed more big telescopes.
It had been obvious for about 10 years from 1978 that we needed big telescopes, another big telescope, and yet we had no realistic possibility of getting one in the near term.
So that there was a period of time where people were very upset.
We almost lost David Lambert to Ohio State on the basis of the Columbus Project and their involvement in Columbus.
It was nip and tuck, and he ended up staying.
But I attribute the fact that he was interested in leaving to this climate that we were living in at that time.
But Holland did what...

what he'd always done he proceeded to move on many fronts at once and i and i agreed with him at that time on this that we tried to get involved with the sophia project using our connections uh through paul harvey and through uh hans mark we moved on the spectroscopic survey telescope through our connection with dan weedman at kent state and there were several other

projects that were thought to be worthy of pursuit that were explored and one by one they fell out they didn't happen we we didn't get involved except for the ssc inspector scott survey teller and that one is now going to come to pass um one last question uh the 107 inch westinghouse was a fiasco as far as the mechanical operation of the telescope i well know that
Do you think that has colored the attitude of the UT administration towards the SST, Spectroscopic Survey Telescope?
Yes.

The history of the UT administration with respect to McDonald Observatory has been that we consistently, from their view, we consistently either lie to them about how much it's going to cost or are incompetent to figure out how much it costs.
